ratings.comment: Awesome. Thats it, just awesome.

Just go to class and you'll know what to study for the exams, but bring something else to do, too. Homework isn't too bad - if you show up at Helen C the night before it's due you can find groups of people doing it. I actually had a TA who gave us the homework answers in his office. Carranza is funny and there are few surprises on the exams.

He's a really funny guy but the material is pretty hard and he doesn't do a great job of explaining everything. Lectures are only mildly helpful but you'll still manage to miss something important if you don't go- tests based mostly on leture. TAs helpful. Homework impossible- lectures don't prepare you for it at all.

This class was the source of much frustration this spring. Lectures were pointless and my TA was useless. HW was impossible, but I somehow pulled off decent grades on the exams by cramming the day before using old exams. Ugh ugh ugh.

PROS: good curve.  Attendance not a must.  Funny.  CONS:    awful teacher. no syllabus/ structure. unclear. doesnt explain concepts well. hard homework.  Thick accent.  Does not care at all about students/ not willing to help. hard final. Bad TA's     Overall:  HORRIBLE PROFESSOR use Business Learning Center for extra help

Juan Esteban was a good professor.  He was always funny during lecture.  Lectures were clear and I liked how he always did the examples and the graphs step by step. Homework was harder than the midterms.
Pretty easy class.  Final was hard, midterms weren't too bad.  Curve is very helpful.  Juan was a pretty good lecturer except lecture was not mandatory because the content wasn't too bad.

Seriously, it's Econ 101, it doesn't matter what professor it is, it's an easy class. But I would totally go for Juan E, he's the man. Very funny and cares, jokes around all the time. I got away just fine by doing the  sudoku everyday in class, but that's just me.

Juan is really funny, whether intentionally or not (check out his appreciation group on facebook.) The class is not too bad, lectures are the most important thing. The homework sets are way harder than any problems on the test, so don't worry if you think the homework is impossible. His expectations are clear, I would recommend him for Econ 101.

juan is hard to understand, he assigned homework that sometimes took 5-6 hours! calculus is not supposed to be a prerequisite and one problemset absolutely required calc.  Just didnt care at all, and made that clear. lots of mistakes in exams.  My TA (Ker Zhang) was terrible also.  I got a tutor and that was the only way I got through.  Not good!

If theres a confusing topic dont expect to be able to pick it up through his colombian accent without a good bit of effort. Also he writes the tests himself and doesnt do a very good job of it. Lots of mistakes. Discussion's definately where its at. Yasushi is the frickin bomb.
his tests were difficult and very concept based. he's disorganized and is one of the most frustrating teachers I've had.

He is so funny. The power lectures are really long but he could careless what you do, 90% of the class was doing crosswords or napping. The tests are easy and really straight forward. Having a good TA (Nissar) makes things a lot easier.

If you have to take econ, take it with him. If you don't have to, then good god, just don't. It was pretty boring, but he tries his best. I heard from my TA that when he gets an exam from them, he tries to make it easier. I have to note, though that my TA, Woo Chang was the reason I actually learned things. He was great, and Juan made it easy.

He is definitly not the most organized professor here but I found his class very easy.  He only explains one or two things per lecture, so you can fall asleep for 20 minutes, wake up, and instantly understand what he's talking about.  Tests were very easy.  He doesn't speak great english but its understandable. Funny guy too.

Parts of the class were not related (lectures, problem sets, discussions), and that made it confusing. Hopefully you get a good TA who provides example problems. Discussion materials helped me prepare the most for tests

Juan looks exactly like Uncle Jesse! Although he is fun to watch, his teaching methods leave something to be desired. He is somewhat unorganized and very repetitive--in the kind of way where he doesn't rephrase anything, just says the same thing over and over hoping we'll catch on. Discussion section saved my butt in this class.

The power lecture was sometimes hard to get through, but Juan, either intentionally or unintentionally, made amusing comments from time to tiem which kept it interesting.  A lot of people had a hard time following lectures, but I thought it was fine.  The problems sets are hard, much harder than the tests.

class was incredibly boring; most of the stuff he talks about is irrelevant. homework has absolutely nothing to do with tests or the class in general. not a bad guy but has serious trouble getting his points across in a logical manner. do not take power lectures unless you need a nap

Class itself was very boring. I unfortunately had a power lecture and slept through about half of them, but I still pulled out an A because I read the book and had the head T.A., Woo Chang, who kicks ass and if you can, try to be in his discussion

Prof. Carranza is amusing and I like him as a person. He tries really hard to make everyone understand but it's kind of hard to follow. Read the textbook before you go to lecture. Problem sets are useless. The exams are conceptual and not very mathematical so you have to really understand the subject to do well.

The weekly problem sets could be difficult, however the exams were EASY.  Got everything I needed from lecture and never had to read the book.  Goes at a slow pace, covers everything well.  Does have accent, however easy to get used to.  A basic knowledge of calc does help a lot with some of the concepts he tought...

I was sooo lucky to pull off a B in this class.  It was SO hard to sit through, and the exams were very tough and usually there wasn't enough time to do them.  He is not very clear in his examples at all, doesn't hold any type of review before exams, and assigns hard problem sets.  Good luck
No Comments

Carranza is a funny guy. Based on what i have heard of other professors, his tests were very easy. He only covers what is on the tests and even tells you what will not be on it. If you have a bad TA (AKA one that doesnt speak english) like I did, then plan on reading the textbook to do well, otherwise, its easy (and I never even went to lecture)

Awful Teacher. I never post on teachers but he was so bad, I felt like i had to. I went to all the lectures and the exams did not reflect lecture as much as he thought. I would strongly suggest not to take econ with him

Good natured and interesting, conceptual approach to teaching. Doesn't use many examples with numbers but teaches basics very thuroughly. Problem sets can be tough but tests are easy, since he guarantees everything on a test has been said in lecture.

He is hilarious, but never does any examples in class.  Either get a good TA or plan on reading the book.  BTW, the book sucks.  Also, his office hours are only for a "last resort" type probem (if the book, your friends, and your TA can't help) so I never felt like I was welcome to come.

This professor has a heavy accent. Firms become "films" and characterize becomes "calatalize". Though you may get used to it, if you do not have too much interest in Econ, it is very likely that you will fall asleep. Tests really arn't too hard as long as you read the text book and keep up with problem sets.
Sometimes hard to understand but entertaining all the same. He tends to be very conceptual.

He is a poor professor. I found myself going to lectures for periods of less than 20 minates just to find out what part of the book he was teaching so I could teach it to myself. Disorganized. He also struggles with his english alot.

It is hard to understand him at first, because he talks with an accent, and says things in awkward ways that someone fluent in english wouldnt.  He constantly draws graphs in class and really doesnt use actual examples, he just extrapolates information from his graphs.  Basically, I end up drawing people who fall asleep in lecture so that I dont

Not very clear sometimes.  Tends to mix up his words.  Struggles with his English at times.  Lectures are Boring and he is nt always prepared.  He is a nice guy, but seems relatively new to teaching.  Try to get a good TA or if possible try to get Prof. Kelly.
Hilarious and informative!! Presents information with easy to understand examples, but is quite repetitive. Tests aren't too bad, not much of a curve.
No Comments
I bring my computer just so I don't fall asleep.  Nothing correlates with exams, lecture, or homework. Has a weird obsession with using hamburgers in every example.

econ is a very hard course and although it is hard sometimes to understand carranza, he is really funny. makes class fun to go to and livens up what otherwise is a pretty dull subject. some of the problems he gives out in the sets do not correlate to what he goes over in class though

This guy is hilarious. He teaches decently enough for it only being his third year. The lectures got much clearer towards the end; at first, however, he did make lots of mistakes on the board, etc. He gives undergrad econometrics a more rigorous and mathematical treatment, which I liked. Also, the TA, Ivan, is awesome.
